blocks.text:
TRIP TO COLUMBUS, OHIO to visit Charlotte and Dick Andes – November 10 to 13, 1950.
Kitty and Gordon left Lancaster November 10 at 5:00 A.M., to York, to Gettysburg, to Hagerstown, to Cumberland, and then on Route 40 all the way to Columbus, through Uniontown, Washington (Pa.), Wheeling, & Zanesville. Generator trouble caused a delay of more than two hours.
The return trip began at 3:00 P.M., November 12, over Route 40 to Washington, to Greensburg, over Route 30 to a point near Bedford for the night. Home next day.
On the way to Columbus, lunch at the Brown Derby somewhere in northern Maryland, beyond Cumberland.

Saturday, November 11 - We see Ohio State defeat Wisconsin 19 – 14. The game was played before 81,000 spectators. After this game Ohio State was named the number 1 football team in the nation, a position Ohio State was unable to hold due to two subsequent defeats.

blocks.text: The Ohio State band plays at half time.
On the return trip we spend Sunday night at these cold cabins near Bedford after driving all the way from Greensburg in vain search for lodging.
A brief pause on wind-swept Tuscarora Summit on the Lincoln Highway as we make a leisurely last lap on our way home.

Through the Caledonia scenic area between Cham-
bersburg and Gettysburg.
View of McConnellsburg lying in the valley, seen from Tuscarora Summit.

End – trip to Columbus, Ohio - 828 miles round trip

blocks.text: Kathy and Cindy about to enjoy a "movie".
Cool day, late November – Cindy, Louise and Kathy

THANKSGIVING DAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1950 – Kitty, Gordon and Uncle Tom Evans see Franklin and Marshall defeat Gettysburg 59 - 20 to close Franklin and Marsh- all's first undefeated and untied football season in the College's history. After the game, we joined Grandmother Landreth, Grandmother and Grandfather Kreider, Aunt Mary Kreider, and the children for an 18 lb. turkey dinner at the Landreths.

blocks.text: December, 1950

December 2, 1950, 1950 – We trade in the 1948 Dodge for a 1950 Chrysler Imperial, 8 cylinder, sedan. Special features include automatic transmission, white side wall tires, windows which operate at the touch of a button, radio, heater, summer air conditioner, center arm rests for front and back seats, leather and stainless steel interior trim, new wide vision rear window.
Kathy with Corky who died soon after this picture was taken.

So ends the year 1950, outwardly calm enough, but with the war in Korea still in progress and with the threat of a third World War on the horizon, which would bring with it the horror of atomic bombing. How foolish can mankind be?

blocks.text: A TRIP TO INDIANAPOLIS, INDIANA to attend a meeting of the Executive Board of American Business Clubs, January 11 - 15, 1951. Gordon and Kitty.

FIRST DAY, Thursday, January 11 - Left Lancaster
4:10 A.M.; entered Penna. Turnpike at Hbg. East (ice); Bedford at 8:00 A.M.; left Turnpike 9:10
A. M. at Donegal; 10:25 A.M. at Monongahela
12 noon at Wheeling, W. Va. (275 mi.), 1:20 P.M.
at Cambridge, Ohio (lunch) (325 mi.), 2:15 P.M.
at Zanesville (348 mi.) ; 3:40 P. M. at Columbus for night (400 mi.). We spend the night with Dick and Charlotte Andes.

Daybreak finds us no further than Bedford, Pa. after driving three hours on the Turnpike at a maximum speed of 25 miles per hour due to extremely hazardous, icy driving conditions. Here the thin coating of ice has begun to melt.
Across the snow covered hills from Donegal to Washington, Pa. Gordon discovers he has for-gotten to bring along any extra suits.
Once again, across the Ohio River via this rickety old suspension bridge at Wheeling, W. Va.

On Oohiihiho o o a militantitcant W. C. T. U.
As we near Columbus, we pause briefly at one of the many wayside parks in Ohio.
In Columbus, we spend our first night with Dick and Charlotte Andes. The four of us, with Kitty's sister Helen, have a late dinner at the Jai-Alai Restaurant.

SECOND DAY, Friday, January 12 - Left Columbus at 10:40 A.M.; to Springfield at 12 noon (50 mi.); reached Indiana line 1:30 P.M. (109 mi.) lunch at Richmond, Ind.; to Greenfield (160 mi.); to Indianapolis at 4:40 P.M. (175 mi. from Columbus). Registered at Hotel Severin. Total distance from Lancaster to Indianapolis 575 miles.
INDIANA STATE-LINE
Kitty stands on the Ohio–Indiana line. Indiana discovered by French missionaries in 1680; was admitted to the Union 1816.

blocks.text:
Greenfield, Indiana, we discover is the home-town of James Whitcomb Riley,
the Hoosier Poet. At left is the poet's birthplace and home; at right is
Brandywine Creek, at the edge of the town, which inspired the "Old Swimmin
Hole".
In Fairmount, Ind. we spend an hour with Bob and Dotty Hummel, shown with son Scott. The Hummels had visited us the night before in Indianapolis.

blocks.text: . Trip to Indianapolis .

FIFTH DAY, Monday, January 15 - We arise to find there has been a freezing rain and snow during the night. Roads are sheets of ice. We barely manage to get up several of the hills in Washington, Pa., but decide, nevertheless, to head across country in the direction of the Turnpike. We spend 1½ hrs driving the 25 miles to Monongahela, being stuck on numerous occasions. Cars all over the road. We get through only by following a coal truck the driver of which distributes his load generously to supply traction for himself. Finally reach the Turnpike in a driving snowstorm. After passing through two tunnels on the Turnpike we are surprised to discover the sun is out and the road completely clear of snow. Make excellent working time at speeds up to 85 miles per hr. Leave Turnpike at Lancaster-Lebanon Interchange. Home before 5 P.M. in time to attend Annual Banquet of Lancaster ABC. Total miles this day 247. Total trip home 649 mi.
OHIO STATE LINE
Sixty miles due east of Fairmount we again cross into Ohio. A constant mist,, with temperature just above freezing.

We arise the last day of the trip in Washington,
Pa. to find the car covered with frozen snow.
Roads are sheets of ice and extremely dangerous
to travel.
After passing through two tunnels on the Turnpike we are surprised to discover that the sun is shining and the highway clear of all snow. We attain speeds up to 85 miles per hour.

The Turnpike crosses the Susquehanna River just south of Harrisburg.
End - trip to In...

pages.full_text:
. Trip to Indianapolis .

FIFTH DAY, Monday, January 15 - We arise to find there has been a freezing rain and snow during the night. Roads are sheets of ice. We barely manage to get up several of the hills in Washington, Pa., but decide, nevertheless, to head across country in the direction of the Turnpike. We spend 1½ hrs driving the 25 miles to Monongahela, being stuck on numerous occasions. Cars all over the road. We get through only by following a coal truck the driver of which distributes his load generously to supply traction for himself. Finally reach the Turnpike in a driving snowstorm. After passing through two tunnels on the Turnpike we are surprised to discover the sun is out and the road completely clear of snow. Make excellent working time at speeds up to 85 miles per hr. Leave Turnpike at Lancaster-Lebanon Interchange. Home before 5 P.M. in time to attend Annual Banquet of Lancaster ABC. Total miles this day 247. Total trip home 649 mi.

OHIO STATE LINE

Sixty miles due east of Fairmount we again cross into Ohio. A constant mist,, with temperature just above freezing.

We arise the last day of the trip in Washington,
Pa. to find the car covered with frozen snow.
Roads are sheets of ice and extremely dangerous
to travel.

After passing through two tunnels on the Turnpike we are surprised to discover that the sun is shining and the highway clear of all snow. We attain speeds up to 85 miles per hour.

The Turnpike crosses the Susquehanna River just south of Harrisburg.
End - trip to In...

We leave the Turnpike at the Lancaster-Lebanon Interchange at 4:00 P. M. after averaging 60 mi per hr. over 177 miles of the Turnpike.

End - trip to Indianapolis.

blocks.text: A TRIP TO THE POCONOS - March 11, 1951. Gordon, Kitty, the children and Grandmother Landreth. Left Lancaster 8:30 A.M; returned 9:30 P.M. Total trip, 380 miles. A cool day with a sharp wind similar to the trip to the Poconos in March two years ago.
The famed Delaware Water Gap where the Delaware River makes a deep cut through the 1,635' Kittatinny Mountains is one of the gateways to the Poconos vacation area.

Y., across Hudson River at Bear Mountain Bridge, to Merritt Parkway, to New Haven, Conn., along Connecticut coast, into Rhode Island as far as Charlestown.
First stop is for breakfast at this diner between Allentown and Bethlehem. First stop is fo rbreakfast at th is diner bet ween Allentowm an d Bethlehem.
Crossing the Delaware River into New York state at Port Jervis...named for chief engineer of D. & H. Canal which passes through it. In distance is monument atop highest point in New Jersey.

We enter the deeply wooooooded area of the Pali-sades Interstate Park which borders the Hudson River.

The Bear Mountain Bridge across the Hudson River is 2,257' long; toll is 25¢.
Hudsonson

blocks.text: Guilford, Conn., settled in 1639 is a beautifully preserved old village. More than 100 houses were built in the 17th and 18th centuries. Many of them bear at the doorway the date of construction and the name of the original owner. We arrive just as the band concert at the green is ending the observance of Memorial Day.
Old Lyme, Conn. boasts of many fine homes and an especially beautiful church, a replica of an earlier one destroyed by fire.

blocks.text:
Mystic, Conn. in the days of sail built everything from clipper ships to gunboats.
The "Charles W. Morgan" (above), more than a century old and the last of her kind,
logged more miles and took more whales than any other ship of her time, bringing home cargoes valued at
more than two million dollars.
The town is a summer art colony and owns a notable collection of clipper ship models.
Plans are underway to reconstruct the town as it was years ago, and it is hoped Mystic may someday be a maritime Williamsburg,

blocks.text: On board the ferry from Jamestown to Newport ($2.25 for car and four persons).
Naval craft in Narragansett Bay.

Old Colony House, Newport, originally built in 173838, and once the Capitol of R. I., was wrecked by the British during Rev. War.
wreckedbytheKettledrby the BBrittishl ddirinngg Reevv.
One of the many palatial and ornate villas which dot the coast south of Newport which gave the town the name of the summer capital of high society during the Gilded Age.
An attractive and restricted beach at Newport.

Newport is more than the summer capital of high society, which reached its apex and social glory during the 1880s, through the Gilded Age and on into the 1920s, with a decline setting in with the economic crash of 1929. During this time almost unbelievable palaces were built by tycoons from New York and Philadelphia and these still stand on the ten mile ocean drive south of the town. The old section of the town, with its narrow streets, is a fascinating place. Still standing are some 400 houses more than a century and a half old. Southern planters spent their summers here prior to the Civil War. Once it was a greater seaport than New York.

Southern planters spent their summers here prior to the Civil War. Once it was a greater seaport than New York.

blocks.text: A stop for refreshments and gas on the road in the rroad too Plymouthmouth. A s ttopforrefreshmentsa ndgasontheroadtoPlymouthmouth.AstopforrefreshmentsandgasontheroadtPlymouthmouth.

First stop at Plymouth is to see Plymouth Rock, "1620", which is covered by a marble colonnade. Here the Pilgrims landed December 21, 1620, after having spent five weeks at Provincetown (see). Plymouth is called the first permanent English settlement in America. Ve and Kitty pose within the colonnade.

blocks.text: A tablet on this hugh boulderhead, just south of Gloucester marks the site of the founding of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.
Route north from Boston.

Gloucester, on picturesque Cape Ann, today is still one of the great fishing towns of the East coast. Gloucester has paid dearly for its traffic with the sea. More than 1,000 vessels and more than 8,000 men have sailed for the fishing grounds and failed to return. The monument is in memory of those who lost their lives at sea.

blocks.text: Ipswich, first settled in 1635, has been known for more than 300 years for its succulent clams. Whipple House (above) was originally built in 1640, with later additions and renovations.
Into Maine, we leave the crowded highway to explore some of the fascinating beaches for which Maine is famous. Here is York Beach.

Just north of York Beach we head out onto Cape Neddick to see Nubble Light, perched on a rocky knoll overlooking the Atlantic. This, we decided afterwards, was one of the most interesting spots of the trip.

blocks.text: Another view of Nubble Light from a bluff on the Cape.

After driving all the way up the Maine coast to see famous Portland Head Light on Cape Elizabeth, we are denied admittance because the Light is on military land and the Korean war is in progress. Not daunted, we drive a quarter mile above the Light, climb out on the slippery rocks to get the picture above. (See trip to Maine in August, 1949.)

blocks.text: Mount Washington Hotel, barely seen through the mist, entertained the Bretton Woods Monetary Conference in 1944. In the back-ground, invisible to the camera, is Mt. Wash-ington, with snow still on the upper slopes, is New England's loftiest peak (6,288').

Due to insufficient visibility, we forego a trip to the top on Mt. Washington via the cog railway, built in 1869 the first of its kind in the world, it makes the 34-mi. climb up Mt. Washington's formidable slope in l 3/4 hrs. There is also an auto road on the east slope.

blocks.text: Right – Our road parallels Pemigewasset River through the notch. Further south at Franklin, the Pemigewasset and the Winnipesaukee join to form the Merrimack.
Left - The Basin, a large, clear pool with a rock overhang formed by the waters of the Pemigewassett. Kitty surveys the scene.

At North Woodstock, N. H., we stop briefly to watch the antics of a chained bear on a pole. Here we leave the main road south through the mountains and head westward over the mountains for Vermont. Soon we once again cross the Appalachian Trail.

blocks.text: It is a little known fact that the State of Vermont existed as an independent nation for fourteen years before its admission into the Union in 1791. It had been admitted to the Union on July 4, 1802 by Act of Congress and was one of only two states (the other being Kentucky) whose statehood required a constitutional amendment; it is also notable that Vermont's constitution provided for universal suffrage before any other U.S. state or territory did so.

Near Barre, Vt. are found some of the largest and deepest gran-ite quarries in the world. Gran-ite is hard, but it can be saw-ed, planed, turned on a lathe, sanded and carved.
The capitol of Vermont in Montpelier has a gilded dome topped by a statue of Ceres.

It had been admitted to the Union on July 4, 1802 by Act of Congress and was one of only two states (the other being Kentucky) whose statehood required a constitutional amendment; it is also notable that Vermont's constitution provided for universal suffrage before any other U.S. state or territory did so.

blocks.text: A large part of the marble used in the United States is quarried near West Rutland, Vt. A hugh hole is cut through the marble bed and then quarried from immense caverns hollowed out of solid marble. The block being raised weighs approximately twenty tons.

blocks.text: Saratoga Springs, N. Y., was the sporting and social center of the latter half of the nineteenth century. Many famous old hotels remain. The most famous of all, the Grand Union Hotel (lower left), is no longer in use and the furnishings are being sold.

FIFTH DAY — June 3, 1951 (Sunday). Southwest through New York state on Route 7 almost to Binghamton, south into Pennsylvania, to Tunkhannock, to Wilkes-Barre, Hazleton, Tamaqua, Pottsville and home at 7:00 P.M. (308 miles).
Our last night spent here just south of Schenectady, the city that "lights and hauls the world" (General Electric & Am. Locomotive Cos)

This scene is typical of the rich farming co-
untry, bordered by rolling hills, through which we travel southwest through New York state.

blocks.text: We enter Pennsylvania at noonoon, and soon pass beneath the Nicholson Viaduct, said to be the highest concrete bridge in the world.
North of Wilkes-Barre we have our only trouble on the trip...a flat tire. We make the change in the hot sun and stop for refreshments soon afterw
Almost home...a final "bite" to eat at a roadside restaurant near Bethel. Rain has again begun to fall after an extremely heavy storm near Tamaqua.

blocks.text: June 24, 1951 - Trip to Beverly N. J. to visit James and his family who have moved into a new apartment. Kitty at home with Cindy who is half covered with poison ivy.
Mrs. Lantz (a neighbor), Grandmother Landreth, Nancy, Gordon, Kathy, Uncle Tom, Roger, James and Duffy; Rory and Louisa are in front.

A ride on a miniature train, the engine of which is a true 2" scale model of a Pennsylvania Railroad engine. The engine burns soft coal and can attain speeds up to 45 miles per hour, although it was driven at only 18 miles per hour on this short track.

blocks.text:
July 1 – 5, 1951. Gordon and Kitty attend the National Convention of American Business Clubs held at the Ambassador Hotel in Atlantic City.
Gordon is elected National President.
For a record of Gordon's activities as National President see special book devoted to the subject.
Gordon and Kitty stand before the entrance to the Ambassador Hotel. .

Delegates from Lancaster pay homage to the new President.
Left to right – Claude Smith,
Nat. Hager, Toylee Snyder, Al.
Alspach (rear), Betty Smith,
Helen Hager, Mary Fran Alspach,
Kitty, Arline Robinson and
Gordon.
Other delegates from Lancaster missing from the picture: Bill
Robinson, Dick Snyder, Marlin
and Mary Albright.

blocks.text: July 15, 1951 - A one day trip to Rehoboth Beach, Delaware for a swim in the Atlantic Ocean. We chance upon the Bards and the Kendigs and decide to rent an apartment for a week beginning the following Saturday.
Picnic lunch en route.
Dick Bard and Cal Kendig.
Gordon, Kitty, Kathy, Margo Kendig and Susan Bard.
Kitty, Margo and Susan.

blocks.text: July 21 - 28 – Kitty and the children spend a week in a motel-apartment at Dewey Beach, just south of Rehoboth Beach. The Bards and the Kendigs occupy a cottage across the way. Gordon finds it necessary to return to Lancaster to work.
Louise at ease.
Kitty ready for a swim.
Louise stays safe distance from the waves.
Bill and Ve Huber visit us over the first week-end. We and Kitty at left; Bill and Ve at right.

blocks.text:
July 25, 26, 27, 1951 - Educators Mutual Insurance Company holds a sales meeting at the Log Cabin Lodge, Medford Lakes, N. J.
Mutual Insurancemeeting at the Log Cabinn Lodgge, Medford Lakes, N. J.

Top row: Lingle, Hoskins, C. Smith,
Haught, Hale, Simonson, Montgomery.
Middle row: Adee, Boyer, Penton,
Haney, McClair, Trump, Strawbridge,
Sheean, J. Smith, King, R. Miller,
Whalen, Snyder, Strickler.
First row: Thompson, England, Gor-
don, R. P. Miller, Grubb, Stanley,
Ressler, Frank.

Herman Hoskins,
John Lingle and Johnn Hoooskkinnns, Gordon stand before the sign at entrance to Lodge.

At the conclusion of the sales meeting on Friday afternoon, Gordon drives to Dewey Beach via New Castle Ferry (new bridge across the Delaware almost completed), a distance of 135 miles; spends Friday night with the family; and returns to Lancaster with them Saturday morning.
